","active":true,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl12_divTabs_1","title":"FAQ","content":"
Q:  Is an LEA required to continue to provide a free appropriate public education (FAPE) to students with disabilities during a school the closure caused by a COVID-19 outbreak?

A:  The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA), Section 504 of the 1973 Rehabilitation Act, and Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) does not address a situation where the closure of all elementary and secondary schools occur for an extended period, because of an outbreak of a particular disease. 

 Governor Tom Wolf ordered the closure of all public schools in the Commonwealth of PA to slow or stop the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic.  Consequently, the Allentown School District (ASD) is not providing educational services to the general student population during the ordered closures.  Likewise, ASD is not providing educational services to students with disabilities during the same period.  Once school resumes, ASD will provide educational services to the general student population and students with disabilities following their individualized education program (IEP).  

 

Q:  What obligation does the district have for conducting IEP meetings during the closure?

A:  The Allentown School District will act in good faith to support the needs of students with disabilities during this unprecedented challenge of school closure. During this time, IEP teams may struggle to convene, as social distancing is necessary, and some IEP team members (parents and staff) may not be available for IEP meetings. ASD plans to organize and hold IEP meetings upon the reopening of our school buildings. ASD will prioritize the scheduling of students whose IEPs or pending Evaluation and Reevaluation Reports were due for completion during the school closure time.  If a parent has an immediate concern regarding the timeline obligations, they are welcome to reach out to the Allentown School District’s Special Education department through the district’s website.

 

Q:  Are there activities or resources that students with disabilities can access during the school closure?

A:  The Allentown School District has created activities and resources that ASD students and families may use during the school closure.  These activities are available in digital form and will be available in hard copy every two weeks at specific school locations.  The materials provided are for all students, including students with disabilities. These activities are optional and will not be graded or submitted for any purpose. 

Special Education Services 

PDE's Bureau of Special Education will provide additional details and updated 

information directly to the public school district’s  Special Education Directors.

 

Q:  Are LEAs (School Districts, Charter Schools, Cyber Charter Schools, Intermediate Units, Career Technical Centers, etc.) required to meet IDEA timelines for evaluations, reevaluations, IEP meetings, and reporting?

A:  LEAs should make every effort to meet federal and state-mandated timelines, including through the use of virtual technology such as teleconferences, to the extent appropriate and available. LEAs should employ typical practices to the maximum extent possible, which includes ensuring parents, guardians, and surrogates the opportunity to participate in federal and state-mandated meetings meaningfully.

The United States Department of Education (USDoE) released the following guidance concerning IEP meetings, evaluations, and reevaluations during the COVID-19 closure:  IEP teams are not required to meet in person while schools are closed.  If an evaluation of a student with a disability requires a face-to-face assessment or observation, the evaluation would need to be delayed until school reopens.  Evaluations and reevaluations that do not require face-to-face assessments or observations may take place while schools are closed, so long as a student's parent or legal guardian consents.  These same principles apply to similar activities conducted by appropriate personnel for a student with a disability who has a plan developed under Section 504, or who is being evaluated under Section 504. 

USDoE:  Addressing the Risk of COVID-19 in Schools While Protecting the Civil 

Rights of Students (March 16, 2020). 

 

Q:  Can LEAs provide enrichment or review activities for students with disabilities?

A:  Yes. Although not required, LEAs are strongly encouraged to provide enrichment or review activities to all students.  If provided, enrichment or review activities must be made available and accessible to all students. If your child attends one of ASD’s autistic support, life skills support, or multi-disabilities support classrooms, your child, should access the Unique curriculum at https://www.n2y.com/.

 

Q:  If LEAs are providing instruction during COVID-19 response efforts, how should they respond to IEPs that they are unable to implement as written?

A:  Special education or related services may need adjustments through the IEP 

process.  IEP teams should work to ensure that students are receiving appropriate services during the COVID-19 mandatory closure and ensuring alignment with aggressive social distancing guidelines.  The mode of delivery might include schoolwork, packets, online learning, or some other appropriate learning adapted to the student's needs and individual situation.  LEAs should continue to follow local policies regarding changing or amending an existing IEP.

According to the federal Office of Special Education Programs (OSEP), if an LEA continues to provide instruction to the general school population during an extended closure due to a disaster, the student's IEP team determines which services can meet the student's needs appropriately.

 

Q:  If school is closed for an extended period, should IEP teams convene to examine the extent to which a free and appropriate public education (FAPE) was or was not provided during the closure?

A:  LEAs are responsible for reviewing how the closure has impacted the delivery of special education and related services to students eligible for special education services.  Once school resumes, a child's IEP or 504 team must determine on an individual basis whether, and to what extent, a student with a disability requires additional services.   The determination of the need for extra services must be consistent with applicable requirements, including to make up for any skills a student may have lost during the closure within a reasonable timeframe.

 

Q:  What should you do if you cannot reach your child’s case manager?

A:  If you cannot contact your child’s case manager, you can contact the following special education professional assigned to your child’s school for assistance.","active":false,"disabled":false}],// required,
                        propPaneId: 'paneId', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propTitle: 'title', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propActive: 'active', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propDisabled: 'disabled', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propContent: 'content', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        tabMode : tabM,
                        scrollToTabEdge: false, // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        disableScrollArrowsOnFullyScrolled: false // optional- pass in default value for demo purposes
                    }).on('ready.scrtabs', function() {
                        $('#'+this.id+' .tab-pane').attr('tabindex',0);
                    });
                };

                activate();
            }
        }
    });

span.hr:
Dear Families,
Beginning Monday, March 30, 2020, the Allentown School District is committed to making a good faith effort to provide continuity of education, planned instruction, appropriate, and reasonable services for students while our schools are closed due to COVID-19.
During the extended closure, all educational services will be provided via remote methods to protect the health and safety of students and those individuals providing education, specialized instruction, and related services. The District will provide all instruction, including special education and related services through on-line resources, instruction on digital platforms, and low tech options such as exchange of curriculum-based resources, instructional packets, projects, and written assignments.
If your child has special needs (IEP, 504, gifted), your child’s case manager will be contacting you to discuss various ways in which your child’s services may be delivered that are flexible, meaningful, reasonable, and appropriate. Special Education Teachers will be collaborating with Regular Education teachers to provide modifications and accommodations for students with IEP's who are receiving Regular Education programming.
The District understands the challenges presented by the school closure and other current health-related limitations that have been placed on all of us. We also understand the additional role that has been thrust upon families during this time. The goals of the online program are to continue the academic and social growth of our students and establish a level of normalcy to their education.
If you have any questions regarding your child’s continuity of education, please contact your child’s case manager so that we can work collaboratively for the benefit of your child. Teachers will be checking email frequently while having office hours daily. If an IEP meeting was postponed due to school closure, or you have an upcoming IEP meeting, you will be contacted to schedule a virtual meeting in the very near future.
Our staff values the education of each child. They are excited to reconnect with your child through these online resources. Thank you for your continued cooperation as we work to ensure the safety of our students, staff, and communities.

hr.span:
Estimadas familias:
El Distrito Escolar de Allentown se compromete de buena fe a proveer continuidad en la educación, instrucción planificada, apropiada y servicios razonables para los estudiantes durante el cierre de escuelas debido al COVID-19, a partir del 30 de marzo de 2020.
Durante el cierre prolongado, todos los servicios educativos serán provistos por medio de métodos de aprendizaje a larga distancia, para proteger la salud y la seguridad de las personas que proveen la educación, instrucción especializada y los servicios relacionados. El Distrito proveerá toda la instrucción, incluyendo los servicios de educación especial y servicios relacionados, por medio de recursos en línea, instrucción en plataformas de difusión digital y opciones de tecnología menos avanzada, tales como el intercambio de recursos curriculares, paquetes de material educativo, proyectos y trabajos escritos.
Si su hijo tiene necesidades especiales (IEP (PEI, por sus siglas en inglés), 504, estudiante dotado y talentoso), el coordinador de los servicios de su hijo se comunicará con usted para discutir las diversas formas mediante las cuales se le pueden ofrecer los servicios en una manera flexible, valiosa, razonable y apropiada. Los maestros de Educación Especial colaborarán con los maestros de Educación Regular para proveer las modificaciones y acomodos a los estudiantes con IEPs, los cuales reciben programación de Educación Regular.
El Distrito entiende los retos que presenta el cierre prolongado de las escuelas y otras limitaciones actuales relacionadas con la salud, que se nos han impuesto. También entendemos el rol adicional que se le ha encomendado a las familias en este momento. Las metas del programa en línea abarcan el continuar desarrollando el crecimiento académico y social de nuestros estudiantes y establecer un nivel de normalidad en su educación.
Si tiene alguna pregunta relacionada con la continuidad en la educación de su hijo, comuníquese con el coordinador de los servicios de su hijo para trabajar en conjunto por el bienestar de su hijo. Los maestros revisarán sus correos electrónicos frecuentemente, mientras mantienen horas diarias de oficina. Si se pospuso una reunión de IEP debido al cierre prolongado de las escuelas, o si tiene una reunión de IEP próximamente, se comunicarán con usted para calendarizar una reunión virtual en un futuro muy cercano.
Nuestro personal valora la educación de cada estudiante y está entusiasmado por conectarse nuevamente con su hijo a través de estos recursos en línea. Gracias por su cooperación continua mientras seguimos trabajando para fortalecer la seguridad de nuestros estudiantes, personal y comunidades.
Para obtener más recursos, haga clic en: https://www.cliu.org/Page/1129

div.div: 31 S. Penn Street, Allentown, PA 18102 | Phone 484-765-4000 | Fax
